description: From Middle English passaunt (c. 1300), from Old French passant.

entries.meaning: (heraldry, of a four-legged animal) Walking, usually to the right, and looking straight ahead with the right forepaw raised from the ground. [from 15th c.]
(obsolete) Currently in use; in vogue. [17thâ€“19th c.]
examples: Many opinions are passant concerning the basilisk, or little king of serpents, commonly called the cockatrice [...].
